title: European Union tramples over British opposition to Greek rescue plan
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Jul 15, 2015, 17:20 BST - UK Markets closed European Union tramples over British opposition to Greek rescue plan By Mehreen Khan | Telegraph – 52 minutes ago Print 
Brussels will press ahead with plans to use a defucnt EU-wide bail-out fund that will put Britain on the hook for €690m of loans to Greece 
The European Commission has ignored David Cameron's objections to using British taxpayer money to keep Greece from going bankrupt over the summer. 
Brussels announced today that it would press ahead with plans to use a moribund EU-wide rescue fund - the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism - to provide a €7bn emergency loan to Greece. 
The plans are set to force the Government in to an embarrassing climbdown, riding roughshod over a “black and white” agreement the Prime Minister had brokered with fellow EU leaders promising the money would never be used to rescue a eurozone economy. 
• Greece news live 
Should the EFSM loan go ahead, the Treasury will be exposed to around €690m of risk in order to help Greece avoid bankruptcy until the end of July. 
European Commission vice-president Valdis Dombrovskis said the EFSM represented the "the best possible avenue" to provide bridge financing for cash-strapped Greece. 
"This is not an easy option, some member states have serious concerns," admitted Mr Dombrovskis. 
Chancellor George Osborne was in Brussels yesterday, and dismissed the idea as a "complete non-starter". 
"The eurozone needs to foot its own bill," said Mr Osborne. 
• EU demands Britain joins Greek rescue fund 
However, Britain could backdown over its opposition in return for a guarantee that its contributions be underwritten by the European Central Bank, according to Treasury sources. 
Non-euro countries would be given some "protection" over their contributions, admitted Mr Dombrovskis. 
One possible option is for the ECB to insure Britain's loans using profits it holds from government bonds. 
Brussels has been forced to use the defunct EFSM after other eurozone members refused to negotiate a series of bilateral loans for Athens. 
Greece's financing needs amount to €12bn over July and August, money it needs to avoid going bankrupt while a third-bail programme is negotiated. That process is set to take up to another four weeks. 
The €7bn EFSM loan will then be paid back using funds from the new programme, according to the Commission. 
Mr Cameron has hailed Britain's "opt-out" from eurozone rescues as one of his biggest triumphs over Brussels. 
The Tory party manifesto of May 2015 read: “We took Britain out of eurozone bail-outs, including for Greece the first ever return of powers from Brussels.” 
All 28 members states are now set to vote on the plans to release the cash. Britain does not have a veto and can be out-voted through the majority weighting system of the European Council. 
Speaking in the Commons today, Mr Cameron said Britain would be ready to send humanitarian aid to Greece if the country is forced out of the single currency. 
"Greece is a member of the EU as well as a member of the euro. It is a friend and ally of Britain," said Mr Cameron. 
"As a member of the EU, if Greece were to leave the euro and wanted humanitarian assistance I'm sure the British public would take a generous view."
